titleStmt.title: Territory of Washington v. Mary E. Teller. Testimony of C. S. Renfield

publicationStmt.authority: Bring Me the Body: A Digital & Print History of Marginalized Habeas Corpus Petitioners in the North American West, 1804-1912

bibl.title: Territory of Washington v. Mary E. Teller. Testimony of C. S. Renfield
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: Am coroner of Spokane County a man came to me yesterday and said there had been a man killed near Deep Creek Falls about four o'clock in the afternoon in company with sheriff Glispen I came to Deep Creek Falls staid over night. this morning I went to the place held one inquest over the body of a man supposed to be Franklin Teller found him lying on his face with his hands underneath him with the left side of the face exposed to view there was considerable blood under his head found blood between house and deceased but none between deceased and gate in examination of the body found the skull fractured on left side found large indentation found no bullet holes found a small hole behind right ear at first glance supposed to be a bullet hole but after examining it closely found no trace of bullet on the skull

The verdict rendered was that the deceased came to his death by at the hands of Mary Teller by the use of a club or cudgel aided by other partners and the killing of the deceased Teller was murder in the first degree
